channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: How France’s ‘Yellow Vests’ Differ From Populist Movements Elsewhere
item.media:description: The demands of the so-called Yellow Vests in France are similar to those of other populist movements, but the uprising is not tied to any political party, let alone to a right-wing one.
item.description: These protests are more akin to the anti-Wall Street than to the right-wing nationalism seen elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Mexico Once Saw Migration as a U.S. Problem. Now It Needs Answers of Its Own.
item.media:description: Migrants playing cards at a sports center turned into a shelter in Tijuana, Mexico, next to the United States border wall.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Tijuana crisis is putting pressure on Mexico’s relationships with Central America, from which most of the gathered migrants are from, and the United States, where most are headed.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Turkey Calls for Arrest of Aides to Saudi Crown Prince in Khashoggi Killing
item.media:description: A symbolic funeral prayer for the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul last month.
item.description: Two men close to Prince Mohammed bin Salman, are accused of helping mastermind the killing of Jamal Khashoggi in the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Putin Vows to ‘React Accordingly’ if U.S. Withdraws From Nuclear Treaty
item.media:description: A day after Washington gave Russia a 60-day ultimatum to comply with a weapons pact, President Vladimir V. Putin said that Russia would “react accordingly” to new American missiles.
item.description: A day after Washington gave the Kremlin 60 days to comply with a longstanding weapons pact, President Vladimir V. Putin’s remarks raised fears of a new nuclear arms race.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Suspected of Crimes, Netanyahu Is Also Suspected of Fear-Mongering
item.media:description: The military operation to expose and destroy what Israel described as enemy tunnels dug from Lebanon began two days after the Israeli police recommended that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu be indicted on bribery, fraud and other charges.
item.description: Critics say the Israeli prime minister, battling for political survival, over-dramatized an anti-tunnel military operation to distract from his predicament.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: The Father, the Son and the Sins of Italian Politics
item.media:description: Luigi Di Maio, Italy’s deputy prime minister, has a squeaky clean reputation, but his father has been accused of illegal activities.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Luigi Di Maio, Italy’s squeaky clean deputy prime minister, has long tarred opponents with the alleged misdeeds of their fathers. Now his father is under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: London Police’s Tactic to Stop Thieves on Scooters: Ram Them
item.description: The police released a video showing officers hitting fleeing suspects on motorcycles and scooters, but though the prime minister backs the tactic, not everyone was pleased.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: After War’s End, a Long Struggle to Patch Invisible Wounds
item.media:description: A war memorial in Kilinochchi, Sri Lanka, in March. Thousands of Sri Lankans died or disappeared in a brutal civil war that ended in 2009.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A government psychiatrist in Sri Lanka goes door to door in an area scarred by civil war, doing whatever he can to meet a staggering need for help.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: U.K. Student Describes Horrors of Life in an Emirati Jail
item.media:description: Matthew Hedges said his captors repeatedly accused him of spying for Britain and forced him to confess.
item.description: Accused of spying, Matthew Hedges was freed last week after public pressure from London, and after seven months of harsh treatment at his captors’ hands.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: To Feed U.S. Troops, Businessman Violated Iran Sanctions, Charges Say
item.media:description: Federal prosecutors says the owner of company with more than $8 billion in contracts to supply troops in Afghanistan violated sanctions on Iran.
item.description: The federal government charged a Clinton supporter, Abul Huda Farouki of the Anham company, with defrauding it by shipping to Afghanistan through Iran.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction

item.title: Lego Foundation and Sesame Street Team Up to Help Refugee Children
item.media:description: A Rohingya refugee camp in Bangladesh. The Lego Foundation, Sesame Workshop and refugee aid organizations are teaming to create play-based learning programs for children up to age 6 in Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq and Bangladesh.
item.description: A $100 million grant from the Lego Foundation will allow Sesame Workshop and aid groups to develop education programs for Syrian and Rohingya children.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: 500-Year-Old Skeleton Found in London (Thigh-High Boots and All)
item.description: The discovery of the remains by the River Thames provided a glimpse into the life of a man in medieval times.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Cuba Will Allow Full Internet Access on Phones Starting This Week
item.media:description: Using smartphones in Havana.
item.description: Until now, Cubans have had access only to state-run email accounts on their mobile phones.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Rise Like a ‘Speeding Freight Train’ in 2018
item.description: Worldwide, carbon emissions are expected to increase by 2.7 percent in 2018, according to studies published Wednesday by the Global Carbon Project.
item.dc:creator: KENDRA PIERRE-LOUIS

item.title: George Bush, Stocks, CBS: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: George Bush’s service dog, Sully, visited the Capitol Rotunda on Tuesday. A funeral service for the former president will be held in Washington today.
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Global Markets Fall After a Wall Street Sell-Off Spurred by Trump Tweets
item.description: Uncertainty over the stability of a trade war truce between Washington and Beijing has renewed investor worries about global growth prospects.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Can We Grow More Food on Less Land? We’ll Have To, a New Study Finds
item.media:description: Harvesting soybeans in Mato Grosso, Brazil.
item.description: To make meaningful progress on climate change, cows and wheat fields will have to become radically more efficient.
item.dc:creator: BRAD PLUMER

item.title: Khashoggi, Bush Funeral, France Protests: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Italy and 3 Other Nations Arrest Members of Mafia
item.media:description: Settimio Mineo, center, a mob chief in Sicily, was arrested on Tuesday.
item.description: The Italian authorities arrested 46 members of the Sicilian Mafia, a day before Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands detained members of a southern Italian criminal enterprise.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: These 5 Numbers Explain Why the French Are in the Streets
item.media:description: Graffiti equating President Emmanuel Macron to the king during the French Revolution, on the Palais Garnier opera house in Paris this week.
item.description: The “Yellow Vest” movement has morphed into an outcry over problems that have plagued France for years: declining living standards and eroding purchasing power.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: U.S. Gives Russia a Deadline on Nuclear Treaty
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo warned Moscow that it had 60 days to stop violating the landmark Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Houthi Delegation Leaves Yemen for Talks in Sweden
item.media:description: The United Nations envoy to Yemen, Martin Griffiths, was also on the Kuwaiti airliner that left Sana, the capital, on Tuesday.
item.description: A U.N. envoy accompanied the negotiating team for the first talks with the Saudi-led coalition since 2016. The war has killed an estimated 57,000 people.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Playing Host to Climate Conference, Poland Promotes Coal
item.media:description: The Polish Coal Miners Band performing in Katowice on Tuesday, the feast day of St. Barbara, patron saint of miners.
item.description: As delegates to a United Nations climate conference discussed ways to tackle global warming, Poland made clear that it will not give up on coal anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Nearly 132 Million People Will Need Aid, U.N. Says in 2019 Appeal
item.media:description: A water collection point in Bani Hassan, Yemen. The biggest humanitarian challenge in 2019 will be the three-year old conflict in Yemen.
item.description: The U.N. is seeking about $25 billion, an increase of about 10 percent, even though relief agencies are becoming more efficient.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Italy Says 5 Egyptian Security Officials Are Suspects in Student’s Death
item.media:description: A protester held a picture of Giulio Regeni outside the Egyptian Embassy in Rome in 2016, just after Mr. Regeni was found dead in Cairo.
item.description: Giulio Regeni, a doctoral student at Cambridge, was found dead in Cairo in 2016. His killing has vexed relations between Egypt and Italy ever since.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: U.K.’s Theresa May Suffers Defeats in Parliament as Hopes Fade for Brexit Deal
item.media:description: Supporters and opponents of Britain’s departure from the European Union faced off outside the Houses of Parliament in London on Monday.
item.description: Britain’s Parliament is reasserting control over the Brexit process, leaving Mrs. May in deep trouble before a critical vote on Dec. 11.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Gunmen Kill 31 Construction Workers in Indonesia’s Papua Province, Officials Say
item.media:description: Indonesian soldiers prepared coffins on Tuesday for construction workers said to have been killed in in Papua Province.
item.description: The workers were brought in to build a major highway in Papua Province. The police blamed separatists, but clan violence is also a problem there.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and MUKTITA SUHARTONO

item.title: Pompeo Questions the Value of International Groups Like U.N. and E.U.
item.description: Speaking in Brussels, the secretary of state said that some institutions fail to serve their member nations, and should be revised or eliminated.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)

item.title: Afghan Women’s Soccer Team Accuses Officials of Sexual Abuse
item.media:description: A soccer tournament in Kabul, Afghanistan, in 2013 to select players for the women’s national team. Officials from the Afghanistan Football Federation have been accused of abusing team members.
item.description: The government is investigating allegations that players on the national team were abused, including by the head of Afghanistan’s soccer federation.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: France Suspends Fuel Tax Increase That Spurred Violent Protests
item.media:description: Prime Minister Édouard Philippe, center, before announcing the suspension on rising fuel taxes in Paris on Tuesday.
item.description: Through weeks of unrest, President Emmanuel Macron has been accused of ignoring the complaints of the “Yellow Vest” movement.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Donald Trump, Wisconsin, George Bush: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Former President George Bush is the 11th president to lie in state in the U.S. Capitol.
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Australia dispatch: Were These Killings a ‘Massacre’? And Who Gets to Decide?
item.media:description: The Elliston Massacre Reconciliation Monument.
item.media:credit: Stephen Dupont for The New York Times
item.description: A small coastal town had a bitter fight over a monument, and in the end Aboriginal Australians saw their version of history told.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Israel Moves to Seal Hezbollah Tunnels at Lebanon Border
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier at the border with Lebanon in northern Israel in September. Israel has been building defensive obstacles along a roughly seven-mile stretch of its border with Lebanon since 2015.
item.description: The military action, called Operation Northern Shield, is aimed in part at limiting Iran’s regional ambitions, Israeli officials said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Australia’s Liberal Party, Seeking to Project Stability, Tries to End Leadership Coups
item.description: Internal power struggles and a revolving door to the post of prime minister have cost the governing Liberal Party at the polls.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Saudis Disqualified from Hosting Chess Match After Israelis Complain
item.media:description: The Rapid and Blitz Chess Championships in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, last year.
item.description: The decision by the governing body for international chess is an image setback for the kingdom, which denied visas to Israeli players in 2017.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: France’s Yellow Vest Protests: The Movement That Has Put Paris on Edge
item.media:description: The third weekend of protests in Paris was by far the most damaging. Apart from the graffiti, there was damage to artifacts kept inside the Arc de Triomphe.
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The grass-roots protests present President Emmanuel Macron with a potential political crisis. More mayhem may put his ability to govern into question.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Mexico’s New President Restarts Investigation Into 43 Missing Students
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico created a truth commission on Monday to investigate the case of 43 students who disappeared in 2014, after the police attacked them.
item.description: Just days after taking office President Andrés Manuel López Obrador created a commission to re-examine the case of 43 students who were attacked by the police in 2014.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Trade, Alaska, George Bush: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: What’s Next for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu?
item.media:description: Facing allegations of corruption, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is not giving up easily, and it is far from clear what will happen next.
item.description: While the corruption cases against Prime Minister Netanyahu could end his career, there are enough variables that could allow him to hang on to power.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: With U.S. Soil Achingly Close, Decision Time for Caravan Migrants
item.media:description: Migrants in Tijuana, Mexico, looking toward United States Border Patrol agents on Saturday as they move around on the other side of the fence.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Migrants in Tijuana who imagined the United States would throw open its gates at the last moment now know better. Some are trying to breach them.
item.dc:creator: MAYA AVERBUCH and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: News analysis: Netanyahu’s Obsession With Image Could Be His Downfall
item.media:description: Detractors say Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has an unseemly obsession with his public image, even for a politician.
item.description: Israel’s prime minister faces corruption accusations arising from his efforts to control his portrayal in the news media.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Facing Brexit Defeat, Theresa May Turns to Damage Control
item.media:description: A crushing defeat in Parliament for Prime Minister Theresa May’s Brexit plan could make her abandon her deal, or even force her from Downing Street.
item.description: With a crucial vote in Parliament looming on Dec. 11, the odds are stacked against the prime minister. At this point, a narrow loss may seem like a win.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Denmark Plans to Isolate Unwanted Migrants on a Small Island
item.media:description: “They are unwanted in Denmark, and they will feel that,” the country’s immigration minister, Inger Stojberg, said about a government plan to house unwelcome foreigners on a remote island.
item.description: The island center, housing as many as 100 people, is part of the government’s drive to make life so untenable for failed asylum seekers that they leave voluntarily.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How to Connect Young People to Europe? Let Them See It All by Train
item.media:description: From left: Rakul Sri, Alfie Clarke, Shari Vockrodt and Usman Merchant in Paris, the first stop on their European adventure.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Much has changed in the 46 years since Interrail pass was introduced, but the essence of what it offers — experiencing new cultures and meeting new people — has remained the same.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW TESTA

item.title: George Soros-Founded University Is Forced Out of Hungary
item.media:description: A rally in Budapest in November to show support for Central European University. Hungary’s increasingly authoritarian government has forced the school to abandon its campus there.
item.description: Central European University, founded after the collapse of the Soviet Union, has been forced from its campus in Budapest by the increasingly authoritarian government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: A Big Cathedral, a Big Bill, and a Big Debate in Romania
item.media:description: Romanian priests at the inauguration of the People’s Salvation Cathedral in Bucharest last month.
item.description: The People’s Salvation Cathedral will be the tallest Orthodox church in the world when finished. Many revere it. Others ask why so much tax money was used.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Sri Lanka Court Temporarily Blocks Mahinda Rajapaksa From Prime Minister’s Job
item.media:description: Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was appointed prime minister of Sri Lanka despite opposition from Parliament, in Colombo on Thursday. A court order has temporarily prevented him from holding office.
item.description: The Court of Appeal issued an order preventing Mr. Rajapaksa from governing for now, the latest twist in the political crisis that has paralyzed the country.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and DHARISHA BASTIANS
